trial_identification.studytitle: Interval sprinting and fat loss in overweight women
trial_identification.scientifictitle: The effect of 12 weeks of interval sprinting on metabolic health of overweight middle-aged women

interventions.interventions: Forty overweight women will be randomly assigned to an exercise or control group. Exercise will consist of 8 weeks of interval sprinting with three 20 minute sessions per week. Each 20 minute bout of interval sprinting will consist of 60 mini-sprints of 8 seconds followed by 12 seconds of easy pedaling. Exercise will be performed on a stationary bike and all sessions will be supervised by an exercise physiologist. All women must complete 24 exercise sessions and must make up a session if one session is missed. Exercise training will be carried out in small groups of between 2 and 3 women.
interventions.comparator: A no treatment control group who will be assessed before and after the 8 week exercise intervention.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Total body fat loss. This will be assessed by DEXA pre and post intervention.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: DEXA will be performed before and after the 8-week intervention.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Insulin sensitivity. This will be assessed by a glucose tolerance test.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: A GTT before and after the 8-week intervention.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Visceral fat. This will be assessed by bioelectrical impedance (Tanita Viscan).
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Assessed before and after the 8-week intervention and during the intervention (weeks 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7).

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Baroreceptor sensitivity assessed by software measuring the rise and fall of systolic blood pressure and heart rate.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Assessed before and after the 8-week intervention

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Cardiac output and stroke volume measured by impedance cardiography.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Assessed before and after the 8-week intervention.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Free of heart disease or any other disease that would prevent exercise training, BMI between 28 and 35. No recent history of exercise training. Age between 45 and 55 years. A normal resting ECG.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Type 2 diabetes, smoker, history of heart disease and any other disease that would prevent exercise training, BMI of less than 28 or greater than 35, any medication that would negatively interact with exercise training (eg beta blockers), age less than 45 years or greater than 55 years. An abnormal resting ECG.

trial_design.statisticalmethods: Our previous interventions improved aerobic fitness with a large effect size of .9. A recommended power is .8. Thus, based on a moderately large effect size , a sample size of 10-12 subjects per group would provide a statistical power of .8 at an alpha pf P<0.5. In this intervention we will use 40 subjects in case of drop out. The statistical analysis will be ANCOVA if assumptions are not violated or t tests on the difference scores.

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: High Street UNSW Randwick Sydney NSW 2052

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Being overweight causes increased risk for type 2 diabetes. We have shown that participation in regular interval sprinting reduces diabetic risk in young adult females. However, no examination of older women appears to have been carried out. Thus, we hypothesize that 8 weeks of interval sprinting will significantly reduce insulin resistance in middle-aged women, Twenty overweight women will be assigned to a 8 week interval sprinting exercise group and 20 to a control group. All women will be screened for entry to the study. Exercise will involve 3 x 20 minute sessions of interval sprinting for 8 weeks. Fitness (sub max test), body composition (DEXA), metabolic status (GTT, insulin), autonomic state (heart rate variability, baroreceptor sensitivity), cardiovascular (blood pressure, arterial stiffness, muscle blood flow, cardiac output, stroke volume), and blood markers (insulin, natriuretic peptides, cytokines) will be assessed before and after the 8 week intervention.

ethicscommitee.ethicaddress: Medical Faculty UNSW High Street Randwick Sydney NSW 2052
